security_audit.summary: Pure Python computational library for financial modeling with no file I/O, network access, or command execution. Code behavior matches stated purpose exactly.

content.value_statement: Professional financial modeling requires complex calculations for investment decisions. This skill provides DCF analysis, sensitivity testing, and scenario planning tools for accurate business valuations.
actual_capabilities: Build discounted cash flow valuation models with WACC calculations
Calculate terminal value using perpetuity growth and exit multiple methods
Perform one-way and two-way sensitivity analysis on key assumptions
Create tornado charts to identify critical value drivers
Model multiple scenarios with probability-weighted outcomes
Calculate equity value from enterprise value with net debt adjustments
limitations: Requires user-provided financial inputs and assumptions
Does not fetch real market data or stock prices
Does not generate Excel or PDF output files
Monte Carlo simulation framework exists but full random sampling not implemented

use_cases.title: Company Valuation
use_cases.description: Value public and private companies using DCF methodology for investment recommendations.

use_cases.title: M&A Analysis
use_cases.description: Model acquisition targets with scenario analysis for deal structuring and negotiation.

use_cases.title: Investment Research
use_cases.description: Build personal valuation models to assess stock investment opportunities.

prompt_templates.title: Basic DCF Model
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a DCF model for a company with 1000M revenue, 20% EBITDA margin, 5% capex, and 3% terminal growth rate using 10% WACC.

prompt_templates.title: Sensitivity Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a sensitivity analysis on this model testing WACC from 8% to 12% and terminal growth from 2% to 4%.

prompt_templates.title: Scenario Planning
prompt_templates.prompt: Create three scenarios for this company: bull case with 15% revenue growth, base case with 10%, and bear case with 5%. Calculate probability-weighted value assuming 30%, 50%, 20% weights.

prompt_templates.title: Equity Valuation
prompt_templates.prompt: Calculate the fair value per share for a company with 500M enterprise value, 200M net debt, and 100M shares outstanding. What implies a 25% upside at current stock price?

output_examples.input: Build a DCF model for TechCorp with 1000M revenue, 20% EBITDA margin, 10% WACC, and 3% terminal growth.
output: WACC Components: Cost of Equity 11.5%, Cost of Debt 4.5%, Weights 67%/33%
Key Driver: Terminal growth rate has 25% impact on valuation per 1% change

best_practices: Always validate inputs against historical financial statements before projecting
Document all assumptions clearly including sources for market parameters like beta and risk-free rates
Use sensitivity analysis to identify which assumptions drive valuation most
anti_patterns: Avoid using unrealistic terminal growth rates above long-term GDP growth
Do not ignore working capital changes in free cash flow calculations
Do not rely on a single valuation method; triangulate with comparables

faq.question: What models are supported?
faq.answer: Corporate valuation, project finance, M&A analysis, and LBO models.

faq.question: What are the input limits?
faq.answer: No strict limits but practical projections are 3-10 years with 5-year default.

faq.question: Does it work with my financial data?
faq.answer: Yes. Provide revenue, EBITDA, capex, and working capital as Python lists.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. All calculations run locally in memory. No data is stored or transmitted.

faq.question: Why is my valuation changing?
faq.answer: Small changes in WACC or terminal growth significantly impact DCF results due to discounting.

faq.question: How does this compare to Excel?
faq.answer: Same methodology but faster iteration and built-in sensitivity testing without formula errors.
